newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Import deals push South Korean won to lower close.
newsitem.headline: Import deals push South Korean won to lower close.

text.p: The South Korean won ended Monday's trading lower against the dollar on pressure from import settlements, dealers said.
The prospect of massive strikes on Tuesday in protest at the passage of a controversial new labour law had little impact on the market, they added.
The won ended the day at 847.60, down from its opening rate of 847.20. It ranged from 847.00 to 848.00.
"After the central bank's intervention in the morning, no one wanted to move," a foreign bank dealer said. "But dollar demand is still huge, so the won will keep falling."
The central Bank of Korea sold dollars when the won fell to around 848, dealers said.
The central bank has never acknowledged intervening in the interbank market.

"Import settlements are the major factor behind the dollar's strength," said a local bank dealer. "However, it will be hard for the dollar to go higher than 848 this week as there are some export deals scheduled for the end of the week."
Both dealers saw the won moving in a tight 847 to 848 range on Tuesday.
